text.p: These are the leading stories in Botswana's independent midweek newspapers on Wednesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Villagers in Mmankgodi, a village 20 km from Gaborone, damaged government and council property, a shop and a police car and violence after a five-year old girl went missing.
- Executives of the opposition Botswana National Front (BNF) will observe preparations for Britain's general election next month.
- Management at Kgalagadi Breweries averted a half-day work stoppage by agreeing to negotiate a review of pay structures and working conditions.

- Air Botswana has leased its BAe 146 aircraft to Air Zimbabwe for two years and itself leased an ATR 42 as part of a programme to rationalise its fleet. A spokesman said the BAe 146 was proving too expensive to operate and not fully used.

- The director of Community Health Services says that 8,047 cases of malaria have been confirmed during 1997 and 46 people had died from the disease since January, compared with 214 deaths over the same period last year.

- The International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW) is opposing applications to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) from Namibia, Botswana and Swaziland to engage in limited trade in ivory and elephant products.
- An opposition member parliament has criticised a constitutional provision that the president of Botswana must be a citizen by birth.
